**Folate** , forms of which are known as **folic acid** and **vitamin B9** ,
is one of the [B vitamins](/wiki/B_vitamins "B vitamins").[4] The recommended
daily intake of folate in the US is 400 [micrograms](/wiki/Microgram
"Microgram") from foods or [dietary supplements](/wiki/Dietary_supplement
"Dietary supplement").[6] Folic acid is the form of folate used to treat
[anemia](/wiki/Anemia "Anemia") caused by [folic acid
deficiency](/wiki/Folic_acid_deficiency "Folic acid deficiency").[4] Folic
acid is also used as a [supplement](/wiki/Dietary_supplement "Dietary
supplement") by women during [pregnancy](/wiki/Pregnancy "Pregnancy") to
prevent [neural tube defects](/wiki/Neural_tube_defect "Neural tube defect")
in the baby.[4][7] Low levels in early [pregnancy](/wiki/Pregnancy
"Pregnancy") are believed to be the cause of more than half of babies born
with [neural tube defects](/wiki/Neural_tube_defects "Neural tube
defects").[8] More than 50 countries use [fortification of certain
foods](/wiki/Food_fortification "Food fortification") with folic acid as a
measure to decrease the rate of NTDs in the population.[9][10] Long term
supplementation is also associated with small reductions in the risk of
[stroke](/wiki/Stroke "Stroke") and [cardiovascular
disease](/wiki/Cardiovascular_disease "Cardiovascular disease").[11] It may be
taken by mouth or by injection.[4]

There are no common side effects.[4] It is not known whether high doses over a
long period of time are of concern.[4] There are concerns that large amounts
of folic acid might hide [vitamin B12 deficiency](/wiki/Vitamin_B12_deficiency
"Vitamin B12 deficiency").[8] Folic acid is
[essential](/wiki/Essential_nutrient "Essential nutrient") for the body to
make [DNA](/wiki/DNA "DNA"), [RNA](/wiki/RNA "RNA"), and metabolise [amino
acids](/wiki/Amino_acids "Amino acids") which are required for [cell
division](/wiki/Cell_division "Cell division").[8] As humans cannot make folic
acid, it is required from the diet, making it an [essential
vitamin](/wiki/Essential_vitamin "Essential vitamin").[12]

Not consuming enough folate can lead to [folate
deficiency](/wiki/Folate_deficiency "Folate deficiency").[8] This may result
in a type of anemia in which [low numbers of large red blood
cells](/wiki/Megaloblastic_anemia "Megaloblastic anemia") occur.[8] Symptoms
may include [feeling tired](/wiki/Fatigue_\(medical\) "Fatigue \(medical\)"),
[heart palpitations](/wiki/Heart_palpitations "Heart palpitations"),
[shortness of breath](/wiki/Shortness_of_breath "Shortness of breath"), open
sores on the tongue and changes in the color of the skin or hair.[8] Folate
deficiency in children may develop within a month of poor dietary intake.[13]
In adults normal total body folate is between 10,000–30,000 micrograms (µg)
with blood levels of greater than 7 nmol/L (3 ng/mL).[8]

Folic acid was discovered between 1931 and 1943.[14] It is on the [World
Health Organization's List of Essential
Medicines](/wiki/World_Health_Organization%27s_List_of_Essential_Medicines
"World Health Organization's List of Essential Medicines"), the most effective
and safe medicines needed in a [health system](/wiki/Health_system "Health
system").[15] The wholesale cost of supplements in the [developing
world](/wiki/Developing_world "Developing world") is between 0.001 and 0.005
USD per dose as of 2014.[16] The term "folic" is from the Latin word
_[folium](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/folium "wiktionary:folium")_ , which
means leaf.[17] Folates occur naturally in many foods especially dark green
leafy [vegetables](/wiki/Vegetable "Vegetable") and [liver](/wiki/Liver
"Liver").[8]

## Definition[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Folate&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Definition")]

"Folate" is the term used to name the many forms of the vitamin—namely folic
acid and its [congeners](/wiki/Congener_\(chemistry\) "Congener
\(chemistry\)"), including tetrahydrofolic acid (the activated form of the
vitamin), methyltetrahydrofolate, methenyltetrahydrofolate, and folinic
acid.[18][19][20] People sometimes confuse this use of "folate" with the use
of "folate" in the standard [way of naming acids](/wiki/Acid#Nomenclature
"Acid") in organic chemistry, in which the complete compound is called "X-ic
acid" but is called "X-ate" when it loses a proton; acids shift back and forth
between these forms based on the acidity of the solution in which they are
found. In this usage, "folate" is just "folic acid" in a non-acidic
solution.[21]

Other names include vitamin B9,[1] vitamin Bc,[2] vitamin M,[3] folacin, and
pteroyl-L-glutamate.

## Health effects[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Folate&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Health effects")]

### Pregnancy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Folate&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Pregnancy")]

Folate intake during pregnancy has been linked to a lessened risk of [neural
tube defects](/wiki/Neural_tube_defects "Neural tube defects").[22] Likewise a
meta-analysis of folate [supplementation](/wiki/Dietary_supplement "Dietary
supplement") during pregnancy reported a 28% lower risk of newborn [congenital
heart defects](/wiki/Congenital_heart_defect "Congenital heart defect").[23]
The [United States Preventive Services Task
Force](/wiki/United_States_Preventive_Services_Task_Force "United States
Preventive Services Task Force") recommends the folic acid supplementation for
all women able to become pregnant; forms of folate other than folic acid have
not been studied for this use and are not recommended.[19]

Prenatal supplementation with folic acid did not appear to reduce the risk of
preterm births.[24][25] One [systematic review](/wiki/Systematic_review
"Systematic review") indicated no effect of folic acid on mortality, growth,
body composition, respiratory, or cognitive outcomes of children from birth to
9 years old.[26] There was no correlation between maternal folic acid
supplementation and an increased risk for childhood asthma.[27]

### Fertility[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Folate&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Fertility")]

Folate is necessary for [fertility](/wiki/Fertility "Fertility") in both men
and women. It contributes to [spermatogenesis](/wiki/Spermatogenesis
"Spermatogenesis"). Therefore, it is necessary to receive sufficient amounts
through the diet to avoid [subfertility](/wiki/Subfertility
"Subfertility").[28] Also, polymorphisms in genes of enzymes involved in
folate metabolism could be one reason for fertility complications in some
women with [unexplained infertility](/wiki/Unexplained_infertility
"Unexplained infertility").[29]

### Heart disease[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Folate&action=edit&section=5 "Edit
section: Heart disease")]

Taking folic acid over years reduced the risk of cardiovascular disease by
4%,[11] where another study found it did not affect cardiovascular disease,
even while reducing [homocysteine](/wiki/Homocysteine "Homocysteine")
levels.[30]

### Stroke[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Folate&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Stroke")]

Long-term supplementation with folic acid reduced the risk of stroke by 10%,
which may be due to the role folate plays in regulating homocysteine
concentration.[11] The reviews indicate the risk of stroke appears to be
reduced only in some individuals, but a definite recommendation regarding
supplementation beyond the current RDA has not been established for stroke
prevention.[31] Asian populations had greater protection against stroke with
folate supplementation than did European or North American subjects.[11]

Observed stroke reduction is consistent with the reduction in [pulse
pressure](/wiki/Pulse_pressure "Pulse pressure") produced by folate
supplementation of 5 mg per day, since hypertension is a key risk factor for
stroke. Folic supplements are inexpensive and relatively safe to use, which is
why people who have had strokes or who have
[hyperhomocysteinemia](/wiki/Hyperhomocysteinemia "Hyperhomocysteinemia") are
encouraged to consume daily B vitamins including folic acid.[32]

### Cancer[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Folate&action=edit&section=7 "Edit
section: Cancer")]

Studies on folic acid intake from food and folate supplementation with regards
to cancer risk are based on the adequacy of chronic intake. Chronically
insufficient intake of folic acid (below the recommended level of 400
micrograms per day[6]) may increase the risk of
[colorectal](/wiki/Colorectal_cancer "Colorectal cancer"), breast, ovarian,
pancreas, brain, lung, [cervical](/wiki/Cervical_cancer "Cervical cancer"),
and [prostate](/wiki/Prostate_cancer "Prostate cancer")
cancers.[33][34][35][36] Other studies showed that excessive dietary
supplementation with synthetic folate may increase the risk of certain
cancers, in particular [prostate](/wiki/Prostate_cancer "Prostate
cancer").[37][38] A 2017 review found no relationship between taking folate
supplements and cancer risk.[39]

#### Antifolate
chemotherapy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Folate&action=edit&section=8 "Edit
section: Antifolate chemotherapy")]

Folate is important for cells and tissues that divide rapidly.[40] Cancer
cells divide rapidly, and drugs that interfere with folate metabolism are used
to treat cancer. The [antifolate](/wiki/Antifolate "Antifolate")
[methotrexate](/wiki/Methotrexate "Methotrexate") is a drug often used to
treat cancer because it inhibits the production of the active form of THF from
the inactive dihydrofolate (DHF). However, methotrexate can be
toxic,[41][42][43] producing side effects, such as inflammation in the
digestive tract that make it difficult to eat normally. Also, bone marrow
depression (inducing leukopenia and thrombocytopenia), and acute kidney and
liver failure have been reported.

[Folinic acid](/wiki/Folinic_acid "Folinic acid"), under the drug name
[leucovorin](/wiki/Leucovorin "Leucovorin"), a form of folate (formyl-THF),
can help "rescue" or reverse the toxic effects of methotrexate.[44] Folinic
acid is _not_ the same as folic acid. Folic acid supplements have little
established role in cancer chemotherapy.[45][46] There have been cases of
severe adverse effects of accidental substitution of folic acid for folinic
acid in people receiving [methotrexate](/wiki/Methotrexate "Methotrexate")
cancer chemotherapy. It is important for anyone receiving methotrexate to
follow medical advice on the use of folic or folinic acid supplements. The
supplement of folinic acid in people undergoing methotrexate treatment is to
give cells dividing less rapidly enough folate to maintain normal cell
functions. The amount of folate given is depleted by rapidly dividing cells
(cancer) quickly, and so does not negate the effects of methotrexate.

### Psychological[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Folate&action=edit&section=9 "Edit
section: Psychological")]

Some evidence links a shortage of folate with
[depression](/wiki/Clinical_depression "Clinical depression").[47] Limited
evidence from [randomised controlled
trials](/wiki/Randomized_controlled_trials "Randomized controlled trials")
showed using folic acid in addition to
[SSRIs](/wiki/Selective_serotonin_reuptake_inhibitor "Selective serotonin
reuptake inhibitor") may have benefits.[48] Research at the University of York
and Hull York Medical School has found a link between depression and low
levels of folate.[49] One study by the same team involved 15,315 subjects.[50]
Folic acid supplementation affects [noradrenaline](/wiki/Noradrenaline
"Noradrenaline") and [serotonin](/wiki/Serotonin "Serotonin") receptors within
the brain, which could be the cause of folic acid's possible ability to act as
an antidepressant.[51][52] The exact mechanisms involved in the development of
schizophrenia and depression are not entirely clear, but the bioactive folate,
[methyltetrahydrofolate](/wiki/Levomefolic_acid "Levomefolic acid") (5-MTHF),
a direct target of methyl donors like [S-adenosyl
methionine](/wiki/S-adenosyl_methionine "S-adenosyl methionine") (SAMe),
recycles the inactive [dihydrobiopterin](/wiki/Dihydrobiopterin
"Dihydrobiopterin") (BH2) into [tetrahydrobiopterin](/wiki/Tetrahydrobiopterin
"Tetrahydrobiopterin") (BH4), the necessary
[cofactor](/wiki/Cofactor_\(biochemistry\) "Cofactor \(biochemistry\)") in
various steps of [monoamine](/wiki/Monoamine "Monoamine") synthesis, including
that of [dopamine](/wiki/Dopamine "Dopamine"). BH4 serves a regulatory role in
monoamine neurotransmission and is required to mediate the actions of most
[antidepressants](/wiki/Antidepressants "Antidepressants"). 5-MTHF also plays
both direct & indirect roles in [DNA methylation](/wiki/DNA_methylation "DNA
methylation"), NO2 synthesis, and one-carbon metabolism.[53]

### Age related macular
degeneration[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Folate&action=edit&section=10 "Edit
section: Age related macular degeneration")]

A sub study of the Women's Antioxidant and Folic Acid Cardiovascular Study
published in 2009 reported use of a nutritional supplement containing folic
acid, [pyridoxine](/wiki/Pyridoxine "Pyridoxine"), and
[cyanocobalamin](/wiki/Cyanocobalamin "Cyanocobalamin") decreased the risk of
developing [age-related macular degeneration](/wiki/Age-
related_macular_degeneration "Age-related macular degeneration") by 34.7%.[54]
The amount of folic acid used in this clinical trial – 2500 μg – was higher
than the Tolerable Upper Intake Level of 1000 μg.

### Folic acid, B12 and
iron[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Folate&action=edit&section=11 "Edit section:
Folic acid, B12 and iron")]

There is a complex interaction between folic acid, [vitamin
B12](/wiki/Vitamin_B12 "Vitamin B12") and iron. A deficiency of one may be
"masked" by excess of another so the three must always be in
balance.[55][56][57]

### Toxicity[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Folate&action=edit&section=12 "Edit
section: Toxicity")]

The risk of toxicity from folic acid is low, because folate is a water-soluble
vitamin and is regularly removed from the body through urine.[58] One
potential issue associated with high dosages of folic acid is that it has a
masking effect on the diagnosis of [pernicious
anaemia](/wiki/Pernicious_anaemia "Pernicious anaemia") (vitamin B12
deficiency),[59] and a variety of concerns[_[clarification
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify "Wikipedia:Please clarify")_] of
potential negative impacts on health.[60]

### Folate deficiency[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Folate&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Folate deficiency")]

Main article: [Folate deficiency](/wiki/Folate_deficiency "Folate deficiency")

Folate deficiency can be caused by unhealthy diets that do not include enough
fruits and vegetables, diseases in which folates are not well absorbed in the
digestive system (such as [Crohn's disease](/wiki/Crohn%27s_disease "Crohn's
disease") or [celiac disease](/wiki/Celiac_disease "Celiac disease")), some
genetic disorders that affect levels of folate, and certain medicines (such as
phenytoin, sulfasalazine, or trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole).[61] Folate
deficiency is accelerated by alcohol consumption.[62]

Folate deficiency may lead to [glossitis](/wiki/Glossitis "Glossitis"),
diarrhea, depression, confusion, anemia, and fetal [neural tube
defects](/wiki/Neural_tube_defect "Neural tube defect") and brain defects
(during pregnancy).[63] Other symptoms include fatigue, gray hair, mouth
sores, poor growth, and swollen tongue.[61] Folate deficiency is diagnosed by
analyzing [CBC](/wiki/Complete_blood_count "Complete blood count") and plasma
vitamin B12 and folate levels.[63] CBC may indicate megaloblastic anemia but
this could also be a sign of vitamin B12 deficiency.[63] A serum folate of 3
μg/L or lower indicates deficiency.[63] Serum folate level reflects folate
status but erythrocyte folate level better reflects tissue stores after
intake.[63] Serum folate reacts more rapidly to folate intake than erythrocyte
folate.[64] An erythrocyte folate level of 140 μg/L or lower indicates
inadequate folate status.[63] Increased homocysteine level suggests tissue
folate deficiency but homocysteine is also affected by vitamin B12 and vitamin
B6, renal function, and genetics.[63]

One way to differentiate between folate (vitamin B9) deficiency from vitamin
B12 deficiency is by testing for methylmalonic acid levels.[63] Normal MMA
levels indicate folate deficiency and elevated MMA levels indicate vitamin B12
deficiency.[63] Folate deficiency is treated with supplemental oral folic acid
of 400 to 1000 μg per day. This treatment is very successful in replenishing
tissues, even if deficiency was caused by malabsorption.[63] People with
megaloblastic anemia need to be tested for vitamin B12 deficiency before
treatment with folic acid, because if the person has vitamin B12 deficiency,
folic acid supplementation can remove the anemia, but can also worsen
neurologic problems.[63] People who are morbidly obese with BMIs of greater
than 50 are more likely to develop folate deficiency.[65] People with celiac
disease have a higher chance of developing folate deficiency.[65] Cobalamin
deficiency may lead to folate deficiency, which, in turn, increases
homocysteine levels and may result in the development of cardiovascular
disease or birth defects.[66]

### Malaria[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Folate&action=edit&section=14 "Edit
section: Malaria")]

Some studies show iron–folic acid supplementation in children under 5 may
result in increased mortality due to [malaria](/wiki/Malaria "Malaria"); this
has prompted the World Health Organization to alter their iron–folic acid
supplementation policies for children in malaria-prone areas, such as
India.[67]

## Dietary
recommendations[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Folate&action=edit&section=15 "Edit
section: Dietary recommendations")]

Because of the difference in bioavailability between supplemented folic acid
and the different forms of folate found in food, the dietary folate equivalent
(DFE) system was established. One DFE is defined as 1 μg of dietary folate.
One μg of folic acid supplement counts as 1.7 μg DFE. The reason for the
difference is that at least 85% of folic acid is estimated to be bioavailable
when taken with food, whereas only about 50% of folate naturally present in
food is bioavailable.[68]

[National Institutes of Health](/wiki/National_Institutes_of_Health "National Institutes of Health") (US) nutritional recommendations[68] (µg DFE per day for RDA, µg folic acid for UL ) Age | Infants (AI) | Infants ([UL](/wiki/Tolerable_upper_intake_levels "Tolerable upper intake levels")) | Adults (RDA) | Adults (UL) | Pregnant women (RDA) | Pregnant women (UL) | Lactating women (RDA) | Lactating women (UL)  
---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---  
0–6 months | 65 | None set | – | – | – | – | – | –  
7–12 months | 80 | None set | – | – | – | – | – | –  
1–3 years | – | – | 150 | 300 | – | – | – | –  
4–8 years | – | – | 200 | 400 | – | – | – |  –  
9–13 years | – | – | 300 | 600 | – | – | – | –  
14–18 | – | – | 400 | 800 | 600 | 800 | 500 | 800  
19+ | – | – | 400 | 1000 | 600 | 1000 | 500 | 1000  
  
The U.S. Institute of Medicine (IOM) updated [Recommended Dietary
Allowances](/wiki/Recommended_Dietary_Allowance "Recommended Dietary
Allowance") (RDAs) for folate in 2001. As for safety, the IOM sets [Tolerable
upper intake levels](/wiki/Tolerable_upper_intake_level "Tolerable upper
intake level") (ULs) for vitamins and minerals when evidence is sufficient.
The UL for folate refers to only micrograms of synthetic folic acid, as no
health risks have been associated with high intake of folate from food
sources. Collectively the EARs, RDAs, AIs and ULs are referred to as [Dietary
Reference Intakes](/wiki/Dietary_Reference_Intake "Dietary Reference Intake")
(DRIs).[68][69]

The [European Food Safety Authority](/wiki/European_Food_Safety_Authority
"European Food Safety Authority") (EFSA) refers to the collective set of
information as Dietary Reference Values, with Population Reference Intake
(PRI) instead of RDA, and Average Requirement instead of EAR. AI and UL
defined the same as in United States. For women and men over age 18 the PRI is
set at 330 μg/day. PRI for pregnancy is 600 μg/day, for lactation 500 μg/day.
For children ages 1–17 years the PRIs increase with age from 120 to 270
μg/day. These values differ somewhat from the U.S. RDAs.[70] The EFSA also
reviewed the safety question and agreed with United States that the UL be set
at 1000 μg.[71]

For U.S. food and dietary supplement labeling purposes the amount in a serving
is expressed as a percent of Daily Value (%DV). For folate labeling purposes
100% of the Daily Value was 400 μg. As of May 27, 2016 update it was kept
unchanged at 400 μg.[72] A table of the old and new adult Daily Values is
provided at [Reference Daily Intake](/wiki/Reference_Daily_Intake "Reference
Daily Intake"). Food and supplement companies have until January 1, 2020 to
comply with the change.[73]

### Sources[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Folate&action=edit&section=16 "Edit
section: Sources")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Warszawa_Centrum_Nowych_Technologii_UW-3.jpg/220px-
Warszawa_Centrum_Nowych_Technologii_UW-3.jpg)](/wiki/File:Warszawa_Centrum_Nowych_Technologii_UW-3.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Warszawa_Centrum_Nowych_Technologii_UW-3.jpg "Enlarge")

Vitamins C and M as featured on a monument in front of [University of
Warsaw](/wiki/University_of_Warsaw "University of Warsaw")'s Centre of New
Technologies

Folate naturally occurs in a wide variety of foods, including vegetables
(particularly dark green [leafy vegetables](/wiki/Leafy_vegetable "Leafy
vegetable")), fruits and fruit juices, nuts, beans, peas, dairy products,
poultry and meat, eggs, seafood, grains, and some beers.[8][74]
[Avocado](/wiki/Avocado "Avocado"),[75] [beetroot](/wiki/Beetroot "Beetroot"),
[spinach](/wiki/Spinach "Spinach"), [liver](/wiki/Liver_\(food\) "Liver
\(food\)"), [yeast](/wiki/Yeast "Yeast"), [asparagus](/wiki/Asparagus
"Asparagus"), and [Brussels sprouts](/wiki/Brussels_sprout "Brussels sprout")
are among the foods with the highest levels of folate.[8] Folate naturally
found in food is susceptible to high heat and ultraviolet light, and is
soluble in water.[76] It is heat-labile in acidic environments and may also be
subject to oxidation.[76]

Folic acid is added to grain products in many countries, and these fortified
products make up a significant source of the population's folate intake.[77]

## History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Folate&action=edit&section=17 "Edit
section: History")]

In the 1920s, scientists believed folate deficiency and anemia were the same
condition.[78] In 1931, researcher [Lucy Wills](/wiki/Lucy_Wills "Lucy Wills")
made a key observation that led to the identification of folate as the
nutrient required to prevent [anemia](/wiki/Anemia "Anemia") during pregnancy.
Wills demonstrated that anemia could be reversed with [brewer's
yeast](/wiki/Brewer%27s_yeast "Brewer's yeast"). In the late 1930s, folate was
identified as the corrective substance in brewer's yeast.

It was first isolated via extraction from [spinach](/wiki/Spinach "Spinach")
leaves by [Herschel K. Mitchell](/wiki/Herschel_K._Mitchell "Herschel K.
Mitchell"), [Esmond E. Snell](/wiki/Esmond_E._Snell "Esmond E. Snell"), and
[Roger J. Williams](/wiki/Roger_J._Williams "Roger J. Williams") in 1941.[79]
Bob Stokstad isolated the pure crystalline form in 1943, and was able to
determine its chemical structure while working at the Lederle Laboratories of
the American Cyanamid Company.[80] This historical research project, of
obtaining folic acid in a pure crystalline form in 1945, was done by the team
called the "folic acid boys," under the supervision and guidance of Director
of Research Dr. [Yellapragada Subbarow](/wiki/Yellapragada_Subbarow
"Yellapragada Subbarow"), at the Lederle Lab, Pearl River, NY.[81]

This research subsequently led to the synthesis of the antifolate
[aminopterin](/wiki/Aminopterin "Aminopterin"), the first-ever anticancer
drug, the clinical efficacy was proven by [Sidney Farber](/wiki/Sidney_Farber
"Sidney Farber") in 1948. In the 1950s and 1960s, scientists began to discover
the biochemical mechanisms of action for folate.[78] In 1960, experts first
linked folate deficiency to neural tube defects.[78] In the late 1990s, US
scientists realized, despite the availability of folate in foods and in
supplements, there was still a challenge for people to meet their daily folate
requirements, which is when the US implemented the folate fortification
program.[78]

## Biological roles[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Folate&action=edit&section=18
"Edit section: Biological roles")]

### DNA and cell
division[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Folate&action=edit&section=19 "Edit
section: DNA and cell division")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Folat.svg/220px-
Folat.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Folat.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Folat.svg "Enlarge")

A diagram of the chemical structure of folate

Folate is necessary for the production and maintenance of new
[cells](/wiki/Cell_\(biology\) "Cell \(biology\)"), for [DNA
synthesis](/wiki/DNA_replication "DNA replication") and [RNA
synthesis](/wiki/RNA_synthesis "RNA synthesis") through
[methylation](/wiki/Methylation "Methylation"), and for preventing changes to
[DNA](/wiki/DNA "DNA"), and, thus, for preventing [cancer](/wiki/Cancer
"Cancer").[40] It is especially important during periods of frequent cell
division and growth, such as infancy and pregnancy. Folate is needed to carry
one-carbon groups for methylation reactions and [nucleic
acid](/wiki/Nucleic_acid "Nucleic acid") synthesis (the most notable one being
thymine, but also [purine](/wiki/Purine "Purine") bases).[82] Thus, folate
deficiency hinders DNA synthesis and cell division, affecting hematopoietic
cells and neoplasms the most because of their greater frequency of cell
division. RNA transcription, and subsequent protein synthesis, are less
affected by folate deficiency, as the mRNA can be recycled and used again (as
opposed to DNA synthesis, where a new genomic copy must be created). Since
folate deficiency limits cell division, [erythropoiesis](/wiki/Erythropoiesis
"Erythropoiesis"), production of [red blood cells](/wiki/Red_blood_cell "Red
blood cell"), is hindered and leads to [megaloblastic
anemia](/wiki/Megaloblastic_anemia "Megaloblastic anemia"), which is
characterized by large immature red blood cells. This pathology results from
persistently thwarted attempts at normal DNA replication, DNA repair, and cell
division, and produces abnormally large red cells called megaloblasts (and
hypersegmented neutrophils) with abundant cytoplasm capable of RNA and protein
synthesis, but with clumping and fragmentation of nuclear chromatin. Some of
these large cells, although immature (reticulocytes), are released early from
the marrow in an attempt to compensate for the [anemia](/wiki/Anemia
"Anemia").[83] Both adults and children need folate to make normal red and
white blood cells and prevent [anemia](/wiki/Anemia "Anemia").[84] Deficiency
of folate in pregnant women has been implicated in [neural tube
defects](/wiki/Neural_tube_defects "Neural tube defects") (NTD); therefore,
many developed countries have implemented mandatory folic acid fortification
in cereals, etc. NTDs occur early in pregnancy (first month), therefore women
must have abundant folate upon conception. Folate is required to make [red
blood cells](/wiki/Red_blood_cells "Red blood cells") and [white blood
cells](/wiki/White_blood_cells "White blood cells") and folate deficiency may
lead to [anemia](/wiki/Anemia "Anemia"), which causes
[fatigue](/wiki/Fatigue_\(medical\) "Fatigue \(medical\)"), weakness and
inability to concentrate.[85]

### DNA and amino acid
production[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Folate&action=edit&section=20 "Edit
section: DNA and amino acid production")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Folicacid-B12.png/220px-
Folicacid-B12.png)](/wiki/File:Folicacid-B12.png)

[](/wiki/File:Folicacid-B12.png "Enlarge")

Metabolism of folic acid to recycle [homocysteine](/wiki/Homocysteine
"Homocysteine") into [methionine](/wiki/Methionine "Methionine")

In the form of a series of [tetrahydrofolate](/wiki/Tetrahydrofolate
"Tetrahydrofolate") (THF) compounds, folate derivatives are
[substrates](/wiki/Substrate_\(biochemistry\) "Substrate \(biochemistry\)") in
a number of single-carbon-transfer reactions, and also are involved in the
synthesis of [dTMP](/wiki/DTMP "DTMP") (2′-deoxythymidine-5′-phosphate) from
[dUMP](/wiki/DUMP "DUMP") (2′-deoxyuridine-5′-phosphate). It is a substrate
for an important reaction that involves [vitamin B12](/wiki/Vitamin_B12
"Vitamin B12") and it is necessary for the synthesis of DNA, and so required
for all dividing cells.[86]

The pathway leading to the formation of
[tetrahydrofolate](/wiki/Tetrahydrofolate "Tetrahydrofolate") (FH4) begins
when folic acid (F) is [reduced](/wiki/Redox "Redox") to
[dihydrofolate](/wiki/Dihydrofolate "Dihydrofolate") (DHF) (FH2), which is
then reduced to THF. [Dihydrofolate reductase](/wiki/Dihydrofolate_reductase
"Dihydrofolate reductase") catalyses the last step.[87] Vitamin B3 in the form
of [NADPH](/wiki/NADPH "NADPH") is a necessary cofactor for both steps of the
synthesis. Thus, hydride molecules are transferred from NADPH to the C6
position of the pteridine ring to reduce folic acid to THF.[88]

[Methylene-THF](/wiki/Methylene-THF "Methylene-THF") (CH2FH4) is formed from
THF by the addition of a [methylene bridge](/wiki/Methylene_bridge "Methylene
bridge") from one of three carbon donors: [formate](/wiki/Formate "Formate"),
[serine](/wiki/Serine "Serine"), or [glycine](/wiki/Glycine "Glycine").
[Methyl tetrahydrofolate](/wiki/Methyl_tetrahydrofolate "Methyl
tetrahydrofolate") (CH3-THF, or methyl-THF) can be made from methylene-THF by
reduction of the methylene group with NADPH.

Another form of THF, 10-formyl-THF, results from [oxidation](/wiki/Oxidation
"Oxidation") of methylene-THF or is formed from formate donating formyl group
to THF. Also, histidine can donate a single carbon to THF to form methenyl-
THF.

Vitamin B12 is the only acceptor of methyl-THF, and this reaction produces
methyl-B12 ([methylcobalamin](/wiki/Methylcobalamin "Methylcobalamin")). There
is also only one acceptor for methyl-B12, homocysteine, in a reaction
catalyzed by [homocysteine
methyltransferase](/wiki/Homocysteine_methyltransferase "Homocysteine
methyltransferase"). These reactions are important because a defect in
homocysteine methyltransferase or a deficiency of B12 may lead to a so-called
"methyl-trap" of THF, in which THF converts to a reservoir of methyl-THF.
Thereafter, this THF has no way of being metabolized, and serves as a sink of
THF that causes a subsequent deficiency in folate.[80] Thus, a deficiency in
B12 can generate a large pool of methyl-THF that is unable to undergo
reactions and mimics folate deficiency.

The reactions that lead to the methyl-THF reservoir can be shown in chain
form:

    folate → dihydrofolate → tetrahydrofolate ↔ methylene-THF → methyl-THF

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Folate_metabolism.svg/220px-
Folate_metabolism.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Folate_metabolism.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Folate_metabolism.svg "Enlarge")

Folate metabolism

### Conversion to biologically active
derivatives[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Folate&action=edit&section=21 "Edit
section: Conversion to biologically active derivatives")]

All the biological functions of folic acid are performed by
[tetrahydrofolate](/wiki/Tetrahydrofolate "Tetrahydrofolate") and other
derivatives. Their biological availability to the body depends upon
[dihydrofolate reductase](/wiki/Dihydrofolate_reductase "Dihydrofolate
reductase") action in the liver. This action is unusually slow in humans,
being less than 2% of that in rats (and with an almost-5-fold variation in
enzymatic activity), leading to the accumulation of unmetabolized folic
acid.[89] It has been suggested this low activity limits the conversion of
folic acid into its biologically active forms "when folic acid is consumed at
levels higher than the Tolerable Upper Intake Level (1 mg/d for adults)."[89]

#### Overview of drugs that interfere with folate
reactions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Folate&action=edit&section=22 "Edit
section: Overview of drugs that interfere with folate reactions")]

A number of drugs interfere with the biosynthesis of folic acid and THF. Among
them are the [dihydrofolate reductase
inhibitors](/wiki/Category:Dihydrofolate_reductase_inhibitors
"Category:Dihydrofolate reductase inhibitors") such as
[trimethoprim](/wiki/Trimethoprim "Trimethoprim"),
[pyrimethamine](/wiki/Pyrimethamine "Pyrimethamine"), and
[methotrexate](/wiki/Methotrexate "Methotrexate"); the
[sulfonamides](/wiki/Sulfonamide_\(medicine\) "Sulfonamide \(medicine\)")
(competitive inhibitors of [4-aminobenzoic acid](/wiki/4-aminobenzoic_acid
"4-aminobenzoic acid") in the reactions of [dihydropteroate
synthetase](/wiki/Dihydropteroate_synthetase "Dihydropteroate synthetase")).

[Valproic acid](/wiki/Valproic_acid "Valproic acid"), one of the most commonly
prescribed anticonvulsants that is also used to treat certain psychological
conditions, is a known inhibitor of folic acid, and as such, has been shown to
cause [neural tube defects](/wiki/Neural_tube_defects "Neural tube defects")
and cases of [spina bifida](/wiki/Spina_bifida "Spina bifida") and cognitive
impairment in the newborn. Because of this considerable risk, those mothers
who must continue to use valproic acid or its derivatives during pregnancy to
control their condition (as opposed to stopping the drug or switching to
another drug or to a lesser dose) should take folic acid supplements under the
direction and guidance of their health care providers.

The National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES III 1988–91) and
the Continuing Survey of Food Intakes by Individuals (1994–96 CSFII) indicated
most adults did not consume adequate folate.[90][91] However, the folic acid
fortification program in the United States has increased folic acid content of
commonly eaten foods such as [cereals](/wiki/Breakfast_cereal "Breakfast
cereal") and [grains](/wiki/Cereal "Cereal"), and as a result, diets of most
adults now provide recommended amounts of folate equivalents.[92]

## Food fortification[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Folate&action=edit&section=23
"Edit section: Food fortification")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/GrainProducts.jpg/220px-
GrainProducts.jpg)](/wiki/File:GrainProducts.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:GrainProducts.jpg "Enlarge")

In the USA many grain products are fortified with folic acid.

See also: [Food fortification](/wiki/Food_fortification "Food fortification")

_Folic acid fortification_ is a process where folic acid is added to flour
with the intention of promoting public health through increasing blood folate
levels in the populace. In the USA, food is fortified with folic acid, only
one of the many naturally occurring forms of folate, and a substance
contributing only a minor amount to the folates in natural foods.[60]

Since the discovery of the link between insufficient folic acid and [neural
tube defects](/wiki/Neural_tube_defects "Neural tube defects"), governments
and health organizations worldwide have made recommendations concerning folic
acid _[supplementation](/wiki/Dietary_supplement "Dietary supplement")_ for
women intending to become [pregnant](/wiki/Pregnancy "Pregnancy").

Fortification is controversial, with issues having been raised concerning
individual liberty,[60] as well as the health concerns described in the
Toxicity section above. In the USA, there is concern that the federal
government mandates fortification, but does not provide monitoring of
potential undesirable effects of fortification.[60]

76 countries worldwide require mandatory folic acid fortification of at least
one major cereal grain, with nearly all fortifying at least wheat flour,
according to November 2013 data from the Food Fortification Initiative.[93]
These countries are:

    Antigua and Barbuda, Argentina, Australia, Bahamas, Bahrain, Barbados, Belize, Benin, Bolivia (Plurinational State of), Brazil, Burkina Faso, Cameroon, Canada, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cote d'Ivoire, Cuba, Dominica, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, Egypt, El Salvador, Fiji, Ghana, Grenada, Guatemala, Guinea, Guyana, Haiti, Honduras, Indonesia, Iran (Islamic Republic of), Iraq, Jamaica, Jordan, Kazakhstan, Kenya, Kosovo, Kuwait, Kyrgyzstan, Liberia, Mali, Mauritania, Mexico, Morocco, Nepal, Nicaragua, Niger, Nigeria, Oman, Palestine (Occupied Territory), Panama, Papua New Guinea, Paraguay, Peru, Republic of Moldova, Rwanda, Saint Kitts and Nevis, Saint Lucia, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, Saudi Arabia, Senegal, Sierra Leone, Solomon Islands, South Africa, Suriname, Tanzania (United Republic of), Togo, Trinidad and Tobago, Turkmenistan, Uganda, United States of America, Uruguay, Uzbekistan, and Yemen.[93]

As of November 2013, no [EU](/wiki/European_Union "European Union") country
has mandated folic acid fortification.[93]

### Australia[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Folate&action=edit&section=24 "Edit
section: Australia")]

There has been previous debate in [Australia](/wiki/Australia "Australia")
regarding the inclusion of folic acid in products such as [bread](/wiki/Bread
"Bread") and [flour](/wiki/Flour "Flour").[94]

[Australia](/wiki/Australia "Australia") and [New Zealand](/wiki/New_Zealand
"New Zealand") have jointly agreed to fortification though the [Food Standards
Australia New Zealand](/wiki/Food_Standards_Australia_New_Zealand "Food
Standards Australia New Zealand"). Australia will fortify all flour from 18
September 2009.[95] Although the food standard covers both Australia and New
Zealand, an Australian government official has stated it is up to New Zealand
to decide whether to implement it there, and they will watch with
interest.[96]

The requirement is 0.135 mg of folate per 100g of bread.

### Canada[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Folate&action=edit&section=25 "Edit
section: Canada")]

In 2003, a [Hospital for Sick Children](/wiki/Hospital_for_Sick_Children
"Hospital for Sick Children"), [University of
Toronto](/wiki/University_of_Toronto "University of Toronto") research group
published findings showing the fortification of flour with folic acid in
Canada has resulted in a dramatic decrease in
[neuroblastoma](/wiki/Neuroblastoma "Neuroblastoma"), an early and very
dangerous cancer in young children.[97] In 2009, further evidence from [McGill
University](/wiki/McGill_University "McGill University") showed a 6.2%
decrease per year in the birth prevalence of severe congenital heart
defects.[98]

Folic acid used in fortified [foods](/wiki/Food "Food") is a synthetic form
called pteroylmonoglutamate.[99] It is in its [oxidized](/wiki/Oxidized
"Oxidized") state and contains only one
[conjugated](/wiki/Conjugation_\(biochemistry\) "Conjugation
\(biochemistry\)") [glutamate](/wiki/Glutamate "Glutamate") residue.[99] Folic
acid therefore enters via a different carrier system from naturally occurring
folate, and this may have different effects on folate binding proteins and its
transporters.[100] Folic acid has a higher bioavailability than natural
folates and are rapidly absorbed across the intestine;[99] therefore, it is
important to consider the Dietary Folate Equivalent (DFE) when calculating
one's intake. Natural occurring folate is equal to 1 DFE;, however, 0.6 µg of
folic acid is equal to 1 DFE.

Folic acid [food fortification](/wiki/Food_fortification "Food fortification")
became mandatory in [Canada](/wiki/Canada "Canada") in 1998, with the
fortification of 150 µg of folic acid per 100 grams of [enriched
flour](/wiki/Enriched_flour "Enriched flour") and uncooked
[cereal](/wiki/Cereal "Cereal") grains.[101] The purpose of fortification was
to decrease the risk of [neural tube defects](/wiki/Neural_tube_defects
"Neural tube defects") in [newborns](/wiki/Newborns "Newborns").[101] It is
important to fortify grains because it is a widely eaten food and the neural
tube closes in the first four weeks of gestation, often before many women even
know they are pregnant. Canada's fortification program has been successful
with a decrease of neural tube defects by 19% since its introduction.[102] A
seven-province study from 1993 to 2002 showed a reduction of 46% in the
overall rate of neural tube defects after folic acid fortification was
introduced in Canada.[103] The fortification program was estimated to raise a
person’s folic acid intake level by 70–130 µg/day; however, an increase of
almost double that amount was actually observed.[102] This could be from the
fact that many foods are over fortified by 160–175% the predicted value.[102]
In addition, much of the elder population take
[supplements](/wiki/Dietary_supplement "Dietary supplement") that adds 400 µg
to their daily folic acid intake. This is a concern because 70–80% of the
population have detectable levels of unmetabolized folic acid in their
[blood](/wiki/Blood "Blood") and high intakes can accelerate the growth of
[preneoplastic
lesions](/w/index.php?title=Preneoplastic_lesions&action=edit&redlink=1
"Preneoplastic lesions \(page does not exist\)").[104] It is still unknown the
amount of folic acid supplementation that might cause harm.[101]

#### Supplementation
promotion[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Folate&action=edit&section=26 "Edit
section: Supplementation promotion")]

According to a Canadian survey, 58% of women said they took a folic acid
containing multivitamin or a folic acid supplement as early as three months
before becoming pregnant. Women in higher income households and with more
years of school education are using more folic acid supplements before
pregnancy. Women with planned pregnancies and who are over the age of 25 are
more likely to use folic acid supplement. Canadian public health efforts are
focused on promoting awareness of the importance of folic acid supplementation
for all women of childbearing age and decreasing socio-economic inequalities
by providing practical folic acid support to vulnerable groups of women.[103]

### New Zealand[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Folate&action=edit&section=27 "Edit
section: New Zealand")]

New Zealand was planning to fortify bread (excluding organic and unleavened
varieties) from 18 September 2009, but has opted to wait until more research
is done.[95]

The Association of Bakers [105] and the [Green
Party](/wiki/Green_Party_of_Aotearoa_New_Zealand "Green Party of Aotearoa New
Zealand") [106] have opposed mandatory fortification, describing it as "mass
medication". Food Safety Minister [Kate
Wilkinson](/wiki/Kate_Wilkinson_\(politician\) "Kate Wilkinson
\(politician\)") reviewed the decision to fortify in July 2009, citing links
between overconsumption of folate with cancer .[107] The New Zealand
Government is reviewing whether it will continue with the mandatory
introduction of folic acid to bread.[108]

### United Kingdom[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Folate&action=edit&section=28
"Edit section: United Kingdom")]

There has been previous debate in the [United Kingdom](/wiki/United_Kingdom
"United Kingdom") regarding the inclusion of folic acid in products such as
[bread](/wiki/Bread "Bread") and [flour](/wiki/Flour "Flour").[109] While the
[Food Standards Agency](/wiki/Food_Standards_Agency "Food Standards Agency")
has recommended folic acid fortification,[110][111][112] and wheat flour is
fortified with iron,[93] folic acid fortification of wheat flour is allowed
voluntarily rather than required.

### United States[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Folate&action=edit&section=29
"Edit section: United States")]

The [United States Public Health
Service](/wiki/United_States_Public_Health_Service "United States Public
Health Service") recommends an extra 0.4 mg/day for newly pregnant women,
which they can take as a pill. However, many researchers believe this
supplementation can never work effectively enough, since about half of all
pregnancies in the U.S. are unplanned, and not all women comply with the
recommendation. Approximately 53% of the US population uses dietary
supplements and 35% uses dietary supplements that contain folic acid.[113]

Men consume more folate (in dietary folate equivalents) than women, and non-
Hispanic whites have higher folate intakes than Mexican Americans and non-
Hispanic blacks.[113] Twenty-nine percent of black women have inadequate
intakes of folate.[113] The age group consuming the most folate and folic acid
is the >50 group.[113] 5% of the population exceeds the Tolerable Upper Intake
Level.[113]

In 1996, the United States [Food and Drug
Administration](/wiki/Food_and_Drug_Administration "Food and Drug
Administration") (FDA) published regulations requiring the addition of folic
acid to enriched breads, cereals, flours, corn meals, pastas, rice, and other
grain products.[114][115] This ruling took effect on 1 January 1998, and was
specifically targeted to reduce the risk of neural tube birth defects in
newborns.[116] There are concerns that the amount of folate added is
insufficient .[117] In October 2006, the Australian press claimed that U.S.
regulations requiring fortification of grain products were being interpreted
as disallowing fortification in non-grain products, specifically
[Vegemite](/wiki/Vegemite "Vegemite") (an Australian [yeast
extract](/wiki/Yeast_extract "Yeast extract") containing folate). The FDA
later said the report was inaccurate, and no ban or other action was being
taken against Vegemite.[118]

As a result of the folic acid fortification program, fortified foods have
become a major source of folic acid in the American diet.[8] The [Centers for
Disease Control and
Prevention](/wiki/Centers_for_Disease_Control_and_Prevention "Centers for
Disease Control and Prevention") in [Atlanta, Georgia](/wiki/Atlanta,_Georgia
"Atlanta, Georgia") used data from 23 birth defect registries covering about
half of United States births, and extrapolated their findings to the rest of
the country. These data indicate that, since the addition of folic acid in
grain-based foods as mandated by the FDA, the rate of neural tube defects
dropped by 25% in the United States.[119] Before folic acid fortification,
about 4,100 pregnancies were affected by a neural tube defect each year in the
United States. After fortification, this number declined to around 3,000.[120]
The results of folic acid fortification on the rate of neural tube defects in
[Canada](/wiki/Canada "Canada") have also been positive, showing a 46%
reduction in prevalence of NTDs;[121] the magnitude of reduction was
proportional to the prefortification rate of NTDs, essentially removing
geographical variations in rates of NTDs seen in [Canada](/wiki/Canada
"Canada") before fortification.

When the U.S. Food and Drug Administration set the folic acid fortification
regulation in 1996, the projected increase in folic acid intake was 100
µg/d.[122] Data from a study with 1480 subjects showed that folic acid intake
increased by 190 µg/d and total folate intake increased by 323 µg dietary
folate equivalents (DFE)/d.[122] Folic acid intake above the upper tolerable
intake level (1000 µg folic acid/d) increased only among those individuals
consuming folic acid supplements as well as folic acid found in fortified
grain products.[122] Taken together, folic acid fortification has led to a
bigger increase in folic acid intake than first projected.[122]
